name: Methadone (Dolophine)
summary: A long-acting synthetic opioid used for opioid use disorder maintenance therapy and chronic pain management.
description: Methadone is a long-acting synthetic opioid agonist used for maintenance therapy in opioid use disorder (OUD) and for the management of chronic severe pain. In addiction treatment, it prevents withdrawal symptoms and reduces cravings without producing the intense euphoria associated with short-acting opioids. Its long half-life allows for once-daily dosing in OUD. Due to the risk of respiratory depression, QT prolongation, and misuse, methadone must be prescribed and monitored under strict regulations in opioid treatment programs.

contraindications: Acute bronchial asthma in unmonitored settings

items: Chronic severe pain unresponsive to other opioids

sections.text: Full mu-opioid receptor agonist with NMDA receptor antagonism, reducing withdrawal symptoms, cravings, and some neuropathic pain pathways.

adult.oud_induction: 20–30 mg once daily; may increase by 5–10 mg every 2–4 days; usual maintenance 60–120 mg/day
adult.chronic_pain: Start with 2.5 mg every 8–12 hours; titrate cautiously

sections.geriatric: Start lower and titrate more slowly due to increased sensitivity
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; methadone is extensively metabolized in the liver
sections.renal_impairment: Generally no adjustment, but monitor for accumulation

items: Oral solution: 5 mg/5 mL, 10 mg/5 mL, 10 mg/mL

sections.text: Onset in 30–60 minutes (oral); duration 24–36 hours for OUD maintenance.

sections.black_box: Methadone can cause life-threatening respiratory depression and fatal cardiac arrhythmias; only for use in opioid-tolerant individuals under appropriate supervision.
other: Risk of misuse, abuse, and diversion
Use caution when switching from other opioids due to unpredictable potency

items: ECG at baseline and after dose increases in patients with cardiac risk
Signs of sedation and respiratory depression

sections.pregnancy: Often preferred over other opioids in OUD during pregnancy to reduce relapse risk; may cause neonatal abstinence syndrome
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; monitor infant for sedation
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of sedation and respiratory depression

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction (5–10% every 1–2 weeks) recommended to minimize withdrawal symptoms.

items: Methadone’s long and variable half-life requires careful titration
Higher doses may be required for patients on enzyme-inducing medications
Monitor electrolytes in patients with prolonged QT risk
